Authors:
kazuya kobayashi, Kei Tamura, Misato Okamoto, Eisuke
Hasegawa, Kyohsuke Ohkawara
Title:
Phylogenetic relationships among populations of Vollenhovia
emeryi, with particular attention on the evolution of wing
morphology
Journal: Annals of the Entomological Society of America
Keywords:
ant, queen, phylogeny, Vollenhovia emeryi, wing
polymorphism
Abstract:
Polymorphism in wing morphology and thoracic structure is
one of the most remarkable characteristics of queen ants. Wing reduction
in queens is associated with the alternative dispersal strategies that
may cause genetic isolation from normal winged queens. There is
relatively little knowledge about the consequences of wing reduction on
the mating system and some previous studies showed that queen
polymorphisms are intraspecific variation. The polymorphic queens of
Vollenhovia emeryi are divided into the long-wing morph (L-queen) and
the short-wing morph (S-queen). To examine whether the evolution of wing
reduction results in reproductive isolation, we analyzed the
phylogenetic relationships among populations of L and S-queens in V.
emeryi with the congeneric species V. nipponica, V. benzai, V. okinawana
and V. yambaru. The molecular phylogeny derived using mtDNA (ca. 2100
nt) showed that the S-queen morphs formed a monophyletic clade and not
formed clusters based on geographic distance, suggesting that the wing
reduction arose only once and that the S-queen populations will be
genetically differentiated from the L-queen populations. The phylogenies
are consisting with our prediction that wing reduction causes
reproductive isolation in V. emeryi.
